If we write $x = swys^{-1} = t zw^{-1} t^{-1}$ for some $s,t \in G$, then from we have

$$\begin{aligned} {\ell({x})} &\leq \frac{{\ell({ x^n x^n })} }{2n} + { c} \\
&= \frac{{\ell({ s(wy)^n s^{-1}t (zw^{-1})^n t^{-1} })} }{2n} +
{ c}\end{aligned}$$ 

whenever $n$ is a power of two. From #P_main_l2.8 and #(T_qhf, 'quasi-homogeneity condition') one has

$$\begin{aligned}
{\ell({(wy)^{k+1} s^{-1}t (zw^{-1})^{k+1} })} &= {\ell({ w y (wy)^k s^{-1} t
(zw^{-1})^k z w^{-1} })} \\
&\leq {\ell({ y (wy)^k s^{-1} t (zw^{-1})^k z })} + { c} \\
&\leq {\ell({ (wy)^k s^{-1} t (zw^{-1})^k })} + {\ell({y})} + {\ell({z})} +
{ c}\end{aligned}$$ 

for any $k \geq 0$, and hence by induction

$${\ell({(wy)^n s^{-1}t (zw^{-1})^n })} \leq {\ell({s^{-1} t})} + n ( {\ell({y})} +
{\ell({z})} + { c} ).$$ 

Inserting this into the previous bound for ${\ell({x})}$ via two applications of , we conclude that 

$${\ell({x})} \leq \frac{{\ell({y})} + {\ell({z})}+ { c} }{2} +
\frac{{\ell({s})} + {\ell({s^{-1}t})} + {\ell({t^{-1}})} }{2n} + { c};$$ 

sending $n \to \infty$, we obtain the claim.
